intro: Loranthus ngamicus, commonly known as the African mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of various host trees. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while producing its own carbohydrates through photosynthesis using the light it captures. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves and produces white or yellowish flowers that attract insects for pollination. Its berries are typically red or orange and contain seeds that are dispersed by birds. Loranthus ngamicus plays an important ecological role in its native habitats by influencing host tree growth and providing food for wildlife.
